1594 10 July M
r
Bodly to the L. T
re
r
Hague
Maye it please your good L. I have nothing more to signifie for myne owne nego-
tiation, till I heare from your L: It might have steeded me muche for many
respectes, if untill
at her
Ma
tie
had fully resolved, I might either have knowne
by some little imtimation, where uppon it hath stayed, or had somewhat sayd unto
me, to intertaine them heere the whyle. For although I have devysed the best
at I coulde, to aunswear theyr demaundes, yet I see they are not satisfied, and
I am alwayes uncertaine, howe well my aunsweres may accord w
th
her Ma
ties
desi-
gnes. It is signified very nowe by l
re
s from
e Campe,
at
e fift
of this monneth, a parte of
e Ravelin where our soldiers had myned, and placed
stoare of powder, was sette a fyre and blowen up, w
th
200 men in yt, of
which there were very fewe saved, but were either by
e myne, or by our
men after slayne, and many of them drowned in
e water faste by.
The Ravelin thereuppon was presently assaulted, and taken by
e Scottes, whose
quarter was neerest, which is thought a great steppe to
e taking of
e
Towne
And we hope in lyke manner to heare every hower, of some speciall attempt to
be given besydes. For our approches, Galleryes other mynes and workes are
brought soe neere unto
e Rampers in 5 or 6 places, as they were ready, it is
thought about 4 dayes paste, to give upon the Towne in all those places at one
instant, as in the meane season having planted their Artillerie upon 9 or
10 beddes in severall places
at
shootconstant
shoot
daye and night, and kill very
many.
Co: Maurice
in gooing aboute to viewe
e workes, was defen-
ded from a bullet, by e meanes of his Targett, of which a splinter brake
out, and hurte his page staunding by. The wether here for
is moneth
hath been exceeding wette, and wyndie, which hath been a great hinderaunce
to
e advantage of our workes. It is thought
at otherwyse, before this we might
have carryed
e towne. This benefitte we have only
at
e Marishes therby are
waxed very deepe, soe as
e Enemye hath noe meanes to convey in any souldiers
which he did oftentymes before. There is a speeche
at 400 of
Verdugoes
Souldiers
have mutined, and have lefte hym.
Ernestus
we heare doth assemble all his
forces for some speciall purpose, w
ch
is unknowne yet here, but only by conjecture,
having sent already to
e castell of
Wo
, adjoyning to
Berghen
300 mariners, it is
supposed he intends upon the Ile
of
Tertol
. It is advertysed hither from
e Enemyes
Country,
at
e
Co: Charles Mansfelt
, is gone to
e Spawe, leaving most of his
troupes betweene
Arras
and
Douay.
The bruite goeth here
at
e
Prince of
Anhalt
is come to Co: Maurice, as they saye but to see, and salute hym
But by reason of a secret motion, which hath bin made by freendes heertofore,
for a matche betweene
e Prince and the
Lady Emilia de Nassau
Co Mau-
rices sister both by
father
and
mother,
it is supposed, that his co
m
inge is
chiefly for that, But for ought I can perceave, by talke w
th
those
at seem
to knowe it,
e Lady hath no fancie to marie with any Germane.
There are appoynted from hence to goe into
Scotland
to
e Baptisme of
e
Prince

Mons
r
Brederode
e Elder and
Mons
r
Valke
of
Zeelande.
For
at yo
r
L. maye desyre to see a plotte of this siege I endevoured longe a goe to sett
one a worke, but it was not pos sible w
th
any safetie to
e workeman to do
it w
th
any perfitnesse, till our Artillerie was throughly planted. Nowe the
inclosed is sent unto me which is done somewhat sleightly, and in a small
roome, w
th
out any tr
i
ming for
at
e partie doth promise to send me a larger
and exacter. Howbeit he doth assure me
at
e juste distaunce between our
Campe and
e towne, the compasse
e entrenchment, and
e length of
e towne, w
th
the forme of
e Angels, portes and Bulwarkes, together w
th
the fortes, waters wayes, and suche other generall thinges, in that sorte as
they present themselves towardes our Campe, are sette downe in just pro-
portion, according to
e scale of passes joyned to yt, which is only mente of
ordinary gooing passes, accounting two foote to a passe. Although it be
no draught to content your L. yet for
at it is
e first
at I have yet seene
and is done by a skilfull person who sent it me hither in a ruder forme
I have caused it here to be somwhat better drawne, and send it heerw
th
And thus for this present I take my humble leave. From the Hage
July 10 1594
Your L. most humbly bounden Tho: Bodley
